creator: brentboyer@hotmail.com
text:
I have an html form whose name-value pairs I want to upload to a servlet (a jsp 
page, actually).  I am using Tomcat 3.2.1 as the web server and servlet engine.

Originally the html form was written to upload the values using the http post 
method.  The form works totally fine when submitted using IE -- the jsp page 
gets the data and delivers a dynamic html page back.

Under Netscape 4.7.1, the following happens: the very first time that you try 
and upload stuff, nothing ever comes back -- you just see the hourglass symbol 
indicating that Netscape is waiting.

I accidentally stumbled across a bizarre workaround: if you stop that first form 
submission, request Tomcat to load its "home page" (i.e. the index.html file in 
its root directory that has the cat logo on it), and go back and try the same 
form again, then it practically instantly comes back with the correct dynamic 
page.  All subsequent form uploads also work correctly.

Another workaround is to simply have the form upload data via http get.

But it is disturbing that the post operation does not seem to work the first 
time with Netscape.

Also, there is no clue in either Tomcat's log files or the dos shell window that 
I execute Tomcat's startup.bat file in that anything is wrong the first time 
that I attempt to post the form from Netscape.

Any suggestions/bug fixes would be greatly welcomed.

-Brent Boyer

Note: at least 2 other people on the web who seem to have encountered similar 
problems with older versions of Tomcat in the past (ironically, the first URL 
below reports a problem with IE and Tomcat):

http://archives2.real-time.com/pipermail/tomcat-users/2000-August/007885.html
http://archive.covalent.net/jakarta/tomcat-dev/2000/05/0321.xml

creator: marc.saegesser@apropos.com
text:
I can't duplicate this.  I'll leave it open for evaluation in other release but 
it won't be addressed in 3.2.2.

I can't reproduce this in 3.3 - please attach a simple WAR file with the JSP
page and a simple form that can reproduce it. The bug with Netscape 
sending extra chars has been resolved, and most people are able to use 
POST without any problems, so it may be related with the code in the JSP
or with config problems. Please also include details about platform, config,
exact tomcat version.
